name: nytimes
text: The coronavirus has killed far fewer people in Africa than in Europe and the Americas, leading to a widespread perception that it was a disease of the West. Now, a tide of new cases on the continent is raising alarms. https://t.co/85KhOZtS8l

name: nytimes
text: In South Africa, a crush of new coronavirus cases is growing exponentially across the nation. At least eight countries, including Nigeria, Uganda and Mali, recently recorded their highest caseloads all year. https://t.co/85KhOZtS8l https://t.co/uOuApo1gR5

name: nytimes
text: Early on in the pandemic, many African countries were considered particularly at risk because they had weak medical, laboratory and disease-surveillance systems. But governments pursued swift, severe lockdowns that slowed the rate of infection. https://t.co/85KhOZtS8l https://t.co/BOJX2qgnsx

name: nytimes
text: The Africa CDC reports 2.6 million cases and 61,000 deaths, lower than what the U.S. has experienced in the last three weeks. But now, as they battle new outbreaks, doctors are convinced that deaths have also gone uncounted. https://t.co/85KhOZtS8l https://t.co/byHqQ2DRjY

name: nytimes
text: There is evidence that many cases in Africa were missed, according to an analysis of new studies, visits to nearly a dozen medical institutions and interviews with more than 100 public health officials, scientists, government leaders and medical providers. https://t.co/85KhOZtS8l https://t.co/VivSBePR2a

name: nytimes
text: “It’s not our disease.” Some Africans view Covid-19 as an affliction of Westerners and wealthy travelers. And with stricter control measures lifted, public health officials fear that Africa’s second wave could be far worse than its first. https://t.co/85KhOZtS8l https://t.co/am1km4kRzJ
